title: Dialysis Access Infection
diagnosis_topic: Infected arteriovenous fistula in a hemodialysis patient
setup_script: A 60-year-old woman with end-stage renal disease on hemodialysis via a left forearm AV fistula presents with erythema, warmth, and purulent drainage at the fistula site. She reports chills and fever.

dynamic_flow.reply: BP 100/60 mmHg, HR 105 bpm, RR 18/min, Temp 38.5 °C.
Erythematous, indurated area over the fistula with purulent discharge; bruit still palpable; no hemorrhage.
WBC 14 K/µL, CRP elevated, blood cultures pending, creatinine 6.0 mg/dL (baseline).
Coverage includes staphylococci including MRSA (e.g., vancomycin).
Ultrasound shows localized abscess and patent fistula; no pseudoaneurysm.
Plan for incision and drainage of abscess with possible fistula ligation if infected segment extensive.
Infection spreads leading to sepsis and potential loss of access.

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident inquires about timing of dialysis
dynamic_flow.reply: Dialysis arranged via temporary catheter if access is compromised.
Strict aseptic technique during cannulation, patient education.

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident asks about salvage procedures
dynamic_flow.reply: Interposition graft may salvage access if limited segment infected.
Endocarditis should be considered in bacteremic patients.
Tailor antibiotics based on sensitivities; typical pathogens include Staphylococcus aureus.

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident fails to escalate when unstable
dynamic_flow.reply: Patient becomes hypotensive (BP 80/40), tachycardic (HR 125), requiring ICU transfer.

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident proceeds with appropriate source control
dynamic_flow.reply: Patient improves, blood cultures clear, and dialysis via catheter continues while fistula is reassessed.

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident is asked to describe operative technique
dynamic_flow.reply: Resident should describe incision and drainage of abscess, debridement of infected tissue, assessment of fistula involvement, decision for fistula ligation vs. salvage, placement of interposition graft if feasible, and coordination of alternate dialysis access.

critical_decision_points: Recognition of access infection and sepsis risk
Imaging to assess extent of infection and patency
Decision regarding fistula salvage vs. ligation
Coordination of dialysis access during treatment

rubric.resident_feedback_template: Your performance on this dialysis access infection scenario demonstrated You demonstrated strong diagnostic reasoning by promptly identifying the infected fistula. You initiated appropriate antibiotics and considered source control options. Communication of your management plan was clear and structured.. Areas for improvement include At times, escalation of care decisions were delayed. Continued work is needed in balancing access salvage with eradication of infection and arranging alternate dialysis access in a timely manner. More detail in operative planning and technical description would strengthen performance.. Suggested reading includes Infected Hemodialysis Access: Diagnosis and Management (SCORE); Sepsis and Source Control (ACS/ASE Review Manual); Vascular Access Surgery and Salvage Procedures
